node.name: table-connection
node.description:
A list of connections between pairs of routing or forwarding tables, the leaking of entries between which is specified by the import policy.
A connection connecting a source table to a destination table implies that routes that match the policy specified for the connection are available for the destination protocol to advertise, or match within its policies.None

node.name: dst-protocol

node.name: tables
node.description: The routing tables that are managed by this network instanceNone

node.name: table
node.description:
A network instance manages one or more forwarding or routing tables. These may reflect a Layer 2 forwarding information base, a Layer 3 routing table, or an MPLS LFIB.
The table populated by a protocol within an instance is identified by the protocol identifier (e.g., BGP, IS-IS) and the address family (e.g., IPv4, IPv6) supported by that protocol. Multiple instances of the same protocol populate a single table -- such that a single IS-IS or OSPF IPv4 table exists per network instance.
An implementation is expected to create entries within this list when the relevant protocol context is enabled. i.e., when a BGP instance is created with IPv4 and IPv6 address families enabled, the protocol=BGP, address-family=IPv4 table is created by the system.None

node.name: igp-flooding-bandwidth
node.description: Interface bandwidth change percentages that trigger update events into the IGP traffic engineering database (TED)None

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters for TED update threshold None

node.name: threshold-type
node.description: The type of threshold that should be used to specify the values at which bandwidth is flooded. DELTA indicates that the local system should flood IGP updates when a change in reserved bandwidth &gt= the specified delta occurs on the interface. Where THRESHOLD_CROSSED is specified, the local system should trigger an update (and hence flood) the reserved bandwidth when the reserved bandwidth changes such that it crosses, or becomes equal to one of the threshold valuesNone

node.name: delta-percentage
node.description: The percentage of the maximum-reservable-bandwidth considered as the delta that results in an IGP update being floodedNone

node.name: threshold-specification
node.description: This value specifies whether a single set of threshold values should be used for both increasing and decreasing bandwidth when determining whether to trigger updated bandwidth values to be flooded in the IGP TE extensions. MIRRORED-UP-DOWN indicates that a single value (or set of values) should be used for both increasing and decreasing values, where SEPARATE-UP-DOWN specifies that the increasing and decreasing values will be separately specifiedNone

node.name: up-thresholds
node.description: The thresholds (expressed as a percentage of the maximum reservable bandwidth) at which bandwidth updates are to be triggered when the bandwidth is increasing.None

node.name: down-thresholds
node.description: The thresholds (expressed as a percentage of the maximum reservable bandwidth) at which bandwidth updates are to be triggered when the bandwidth is decreasing.None

node.name: up-down-thresholds
node.description: The thresholds (expressed as a percentage of the maximum reservable bandwidth of the interface) at which bandwidth updates are flooded - used both when the bandwidth is increasing and decreasingNone

node.name: state
node.description: State parameters for TED update threshold None

node.name: threshold-type
node.description: The type of threshold that should be used to specify the values at which bandwidth is flooded. DELTA indicates that the local system should flood IGP updates when a change in reserved bandwidth &gt= the specified delta occurs on the interface. Where THRESHOLD_CROSSED is specified, the local system should trigger an update (and hence flood) the reserved bandwidth when the reserved bandwidth changes such that it crosses, or becomes equal to one of the threshold valuesNone

node.name: delta-percentage
node.description: The percentage of the maximum-reservable-bandwidth considered as the delta that results in an IGP update being floodedNone

node.name: threshold-specification
node.description: This value specifies whether a single set of threshold values should be used for both increasing and decreasing bandwidth when determining whether to trigger updated bandwidth values to be flooded in the IGP TE extensions. MIRRORED-UP-DOWN indicates that a single value (or set of values) should be used for both increasing and decreasing values, where SEPARATE-UP-DOWN specifies that the increasing and decreasing values will be separately specifiedNone

node.name: up-thresholds

node.name: down-thresholds

node.name: up-down-thresholds
node.description: The thresholds (expressed as a percentage of the maximum reservable bandwidth of the interface) at which bandwidth updates are flooded - used both when the bandwidth is increasing and decreasingNone

node.description: The value of the metric that should be specified. The value supplied in this leaf is used in conjunction with the metric type to determine the value of the metric used by the system. Where the metric-type is set to LSP_METRIC_ABSOLUTE - the value of this leaf is used directly; where it is set to LSP_METRIC_RELATIVE, the relevant (positive or negative) offset is used to formulate the metric; where metric-type is LSP_METRIC_INHERITED, the value of this leaf is not utilisedNone

node.name: shortcut-eligible

Where the metric-type is set to LSP_METRIC_ABSOLUTE - the value of this leaf is used directly; where it is set to LSP_METRIC_RELATIVE, the relevant (positive or negative) offset is used to formulate the metric; where metric-type is LSP_METRIC_INHERITED, the value of this leaf is not utilisedNone

node.name: discard
node.description: When this leaf is set to true, the local system should drop packets that match the rule.None

node.name: decapsulate-gre
node.description: When this leaf is set to true, the local system should remove the GRE header from the packet matching the rule. Following the decapsulation it should subsequently forward the encapsulated packet according to the relevant lookup (e.g., if the encapsulated packet is IP, the packet should be routed according to the IP destination).None

node.name: network-instance
node.description: When this leaf is set, packets matching the match criteria for the forwarding rule should be looked up in the network-instance that is referenced rather than the network-instance with which the interface is associated. Such configuration allows policy-routing into multiple sub-topologies from a single ingress access interface, or different send and receive contexts for a particular interface (sometimes referred to as half-duplex VRF).None

node.name: path-selection-group
node.description: When path-selection-group is set, packets matching the match criteria for the forwarding rule should be forwarded only via one of the paths that is specified within the referenced path-selection-group. The next-hop of the packet within the routing context should be used to determine between multiple paths that are specified within the group.None

node.name: next-hop
node.description: When an IP next-hop is specified in the next-hop field, packets matching the match criteria for the forwarding rule should be forwarded to the next-hop IP address, bypassing any lookup on the local system.None

node.description: Operational state parameters relating to the forwarding rule's action.None

node.description: When this leaf is set to true, the local system should drop packets that match the rule.None

node.name: decapsulate-gre
node.description: When this leaf is set to true, the local system should remove the GRE header from the packet matching the rule. Following the decapsulation it should subsequently forward the encapsulated packet according to the relevant lookup (e.g., if the encapsulated packet is IP, the packet should be routed according to the IP destination).None

node.name: network-instance
node.description: When this leaf is set, packets matching the match criteria for the forwarding rule should be looked up in the network-instance that is referenced rather than the network-instance with which the interface is associated. Such configuration allows policy-routing into multiple sub-topologies from a single ingress access interface, or different send and receive contexts for a particular interface (sometimes referred to as half-duplex VRF).None

The next-hop of the packet within the routing context should be used to determine between multiple paths that are specified within the group.None

node.name: next-hop
node.description: When an IP next-hop is specified in the next-hop field, packets matching the match criteria for the forwarding rule should be forwarded to the next-hop IP address, bypassing any lookup on the local system.None

Packets ingress on the referenced interface should be compared to the match criteria within the specified policy, and in the case that these criteria are met, the forwarding actions specified applied. These policies should be applied following quality of service classification, and ACL actions if such entities are referenced by the corresponding interface.None

These policies should be applied following quality of service classification, and ACL actions if such entities are referenced by the corresponding interface.None

node.name: path-selection-groups
node.description: Surrounding container for the path selection groups defined within the policy forwarding model.None

node.name: path-selection-group
node.description: A path selection group is a set of forwarding resources, which are grouped as eligible paths for a particular policy-based forwarding rule. A policy rule may select a path-selection-group as the egress for a particular type of traffic (e.g., DSCP value). The system then utilises its standard forwarding lookup mechanism to select from the paths that are specified within the group - for IP packets, the destination IP address is used such that the packet is routed to the entity within the path-selection-group that corresponds to the next-hop for the destination IP address of the packet; for L2 packets, the selection is based on the destination MAC address.None

node.name: group-id
node.description: Reference to a unique identifier for the path selection groupNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to the path selection group.None

node.name: group-id
node.description: A unique name for the path-selection-groupNone

node.name: mpls-lsp
node.description: A set of MPLS constrained-path LSPs which should be considered for the policy forwarding next-hop. In order to select between the LSPs within the path-selection-group, the system should determine which LSP provides the best path to the next-hop for the routed packet.None

node.name: state
node.description: Operational state parameters relating to the path selection group.None

node.name: group-id

node.name: mpls-lsp

node.name: afts
node.description: The abstract forwarding tables (AFTs) that are associated with the network instance. An AFT is instantiated per-protocol running within the network-instance - such that one exists for IPv4 Unicast, IPv6 Unicast, MPLS, L2 forwarding entries, etc. A forwarding entry within the FIB has a set of next-hops, which may be a reference to an entry within another table - e.g., where a Layer 3 next-hop has an associated Layer 2 forwarding entry.None

node.name: aft
node.description: An individual abstract forwarding table associated with a an address family wtihin the network instance.None

node.name: address-family
node.description: Reference to the address family with which the AFT is associatedNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to the AFT.None

node.name: address-family
node.description: The address family of entries that are described by the AFT.None

node.name: state
node.description: Operational state parameters relating to the AFT.None

node.name: address-family
node.description: The address family of entries that are described by the AFT.None

node.name: entries
node.description: Enclosing container for a list of abstract forwarding table entries within the network instance for a particular protocol (e.g., IPv4, IPv6, MPLS).None

node.name: entry
node.description: A forwarding database entry within the network instanceNone

node.name: index
node.description: A pointer to the index of the AFT entry within the network instanceNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to the forwarding entryNone

node.name: index
node.description: A unique index referring to the AFT entryNone

node.name: state
node.description: Operational state parameters relating to the forwarding entryNone

node.name: index
node.description: A unique index referring to the AFT entryNone

node.name: packets-forwarded
node.description: The number of packets which have matched, and been forwarded, based on the AFT entry.None

node.name: octets-forwarded
node.description: The number of octets which have matched, and been forwarded, based on the AFT entryNone

node.name: match
node.description: Match criteria for the AFT entryNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration of match criteria for the AFT entryNone

node.name: state
node.description: Operational state parameters for match criteria of the AFT entryNone

node.name: ip-prefix
node.description: The IP prefix that the forwarding entry matches. Used for Layer 3 forwarding entries.None

node.name: mac-address
node.description: The MAC address that the forwarding entry matches. Used for Layer 2 forwarding entries, e.g., within a VSI instance.None

node.name: mpls-label
node.description: The MPLS label that the forwarding entry matches. Used for MPLS forwarding entries, whereby the local device acts as an LSR.None

node.name: mpls-tc
node.description: The value of the MPLS Traffic Class bits (formerly known as the MPLS experimental bits) that are to be matched by the AFT entry.None

node.name: ip-dscp
node.description: The value of the differentiated services code point (DSCP) to be matched for the forwarding entry. The value is specified in cases where specific class-based forwarding based on IP is implemented by the device.None

node.name: ip-protocol
node.description: The value of the IP protocol field of an IPv4 packet, or the next-header field of an IPv6 packet which is to be matched by the AFT entry. This field is utilised where forwarding is performed based on L4 information.None

node.name: l4-src-port
node.description: The value of the source port field of the transport header that is to be matched by the AFT entry.None

node.name: l4-dst-port
node.description: The value of the destination port field of the transport header that is to be matched by the AFT entry.None

node.name: oc-aftni:origin-network-instance
node.description:
If the AFT entry was imported from another network instance (e.g., it corresponds to a L3 forwarding entry which was learned within another network-instance), the value of this leaf reflects the network-instance from which it was learned.
For example, if the local network-instance corresponds to a L3VRF, and routes are imported from the VPNv4 address-family of the BGP instance in the DEFAULT_INSTANCE, then this value would reflect the DEFAULT_INSTANCE as the origin-network-instance.None

node.description: Reference to a base interface. If a reference to a subinterface is required, this leaf must be specified to indicate the base interface.None

node.name: subinterface
node.description: Reference to a subinterface -- this requires the base interface to be specified using the interface leaf in this container. If only a reference to a base interface is requuired, this leaf should not be set.None

node.name: next-hops
node.description: Enclosing container for the list of next-hops associated with the forwarding entryNone

node.name: next-hop
node.description: A next-hop associated with the forwarding instance. The entries within the next-hop list should only reflect next-hops that are actively used by the local system. That is to say inactive, backup or FRR next-hops should not be included within this list.None

node.name: index
node.description: A unique index identifying the next-hop entry for the AFT entryNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to the AFT next-hop entryNone

node.name: index
node.description: A unique entry for the next-hopNone

node.name: state
node.description: Operational state parameters relating to the AFT next-hop entryNone

node.name: index
node.description: A unique entry for the next-hopNone

node.name: weight
node.description: The weight of the next-hop. Traffic is balanced according to the ratio described by the relative weights of the next hops that exist for the AFT entry. Note that all next-hops that are specified are assumed to be active next-hops and therefore eligible (and selected) to be installed in the FIB, and hence used for packet forwarding.None

node.name: ip-address
node.description: The IP address of the next-hop system.None

node.name: mac-address
node.description: The MAC address of the next-hop if resolved by the local network instance.None

node.name: popped-mpls-label-stack
node.description:
The MPLS label stack to be popped from the packet when switched by the system. The stack is encoding as a leaf-list whereby the other of the entries is such that the first entry is the label lowest down the label stack to be popped.
If the local system pops the outer-most label 400, then the value of this list is [400,]. If the local system removes two labels, the outer-most being 500, and the second of which is 500, then the value of the list is [500, 400].
A swap operation is reflected by entries in the popped-mpls-label-stack and pushed-mpls-label-stack nodes.None

node.name: pushed-mpls-label-stack
node.description:
The MPLS label stack imposed when forwarding packets to the next-hop - the stack is encoded as a leaf list whereby the order of the entries is such that the first entry in the list is the label at the bottom of the stack to be pushed.
To this end, a packet which is to forwarded to a device using a service label of 42, and a transport label of 8072 will be represented with a label stack list of [42, 8072].
The MPLS label stack list is ordered by the user, such that no system re-ordering of leaves is permitted by the system.
A swap operation is reflected by entries in the popped-mpls-label-stack and pushed-mpls-label-stack nodes.None

node.name: decapsulate-header
node.description: When forwarding a packet to the specified next-hop, the local system performs a decapsulation of the packet - removing the specified header type. In the case that no next-hop is specified, the packet header is removed, and a subsequent forwarding lookup is performed on the packet encapsulated within the header, matched within the relevant AFT within the specified network-instance.None

node.name: encapsulate-header
node.description: When forwarding a packet to the specified next-hop the local system performs an encapsulation of the packet - adding the specified header type.None

node.name: origin-protocol
node.description: The protocol from which the AFT entry was learned.None

node.name: oc-aftni:network-instance
node.description: The network-instance within which the next-hop should be resolved. When this leaf is unspecified, the next-hop is resolved within the local instance.None

The lower the metric specified the more preferable the RIB entry is to be selected for use within the network instance. Where multiple entries have the same metric value then these equal cost paths should be treated according to the specified ECMP path selection behaviour for the instanceNone

node.description: A list of next-hops to be utilised for the static route being specified.None

node.name: index
node.description: A reference to the index of the current next-hop. The index is intended to be a user-specified value which can be used to reference the next-hop in question, without any other semantics being assigned to it.None

node.description: Configuration parameters relating to the next-hop entryNone

node.name: index
node.description: An user-specified identifier utilised to uniquely reference the next-hop entry in the next-hop list. The value of this index has no semantic meaning other than for referencing the entry.None

node.name: next-hop
node.description: The next-hop that is to be used for the static route - this may be specified as an IP address, an interface or a pre-defined next-hop type - for instance, DROP or LOCAL_LINK. When this leaf is not set, and the interface-ref value is specified for the next-hop, then the system should treat the prefix as though it is directly connected to the interface.None

node.name: metric
node.description: A metric which is utilised to specify the preference of the next-hop entry when it is injected into the RIB. The lower the metric, the more preferable the prefix is. When this value is not specified the metric is inherited from the default metric utilised for static routes within the network instance that the static routes are being instantiated. When multiple next-hops are specified for a static route, the metric is utilised to determine which of the next-hops is to be installed in the RIB. When multiple next-hops have the same metric (be it specified, or simply the default) then these next-hops should all be installed in the RIBNone

node.name: recurse
node.description: Determines whether the next-hop should be allowed to be looked up recursively - i.e., via a RIB entry which has been installed by a routing protocol, or another static route - rather than needing to be connected directly to an interface of the local system within the current network instance. When the interface reference specified within the next-hop entry is set (i.e., is not null) then forwarding is restricted to being via the interface specified - and recursion is hence disabled.None

node.name: index

node.name: next-hop

When this leaf is not set, and the interface-ref value is specified for the next-hop, then the system should treat the prefix as though it is directly connected to the interface.None

node.name: metric

When this value is not specified the metric is inherited from the default metric utilised for static routes within the network instance that the static routes are being instantiated. When multiple next-hops are specified for a static route, the metric is utilised to determine which of the next-hops is to be installed in the RIB. When multiple next-hops have the same metric (be it specified, or simply the default) then these next-hops should all be installed in the RIBNone

node.name: recurse

node.name: restart-time
node.description: Estimated time (in seconds) for the local BGP speaker to restart a session. This value is advertise in the graceful restart BGP capability. This is a 12-bit value, referred to as Restart Time in RFC4724. Per RFC4724, the suggested default value is &lt= the hold-time value.None

node.name: stale-routes-time
node.description: An upper-bound on the time thate stale routes will be retained by a router after a session is restarted. If an End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths will be purged. This timer is referred to as the Selection_Deferral_Timer in RFC4724None

node.name: helper-only
node.description: Enable graceful-restart in helper mode only. When this leaf is set, the local system does not retain forwarding its own state during a restart, but supports procedures for the receiving speaker, as defined in RFC4724.None

node.name: state
node.description: State information associated with graceful-restartNone

node.name: enabled
node.description: Enable or disable the graceful-restart capability.None

node.name: restart-time
node.description: Estimated time (in seconds) for the local BGP speaker to restart a session. This value is advertise in the graceful restart BGP capability. This is a 12-bit value, referred to as Restart Time in RFC4724. Per RFC4724, the suggested default value is &lt= the hold-time value.None

node.name: stale-routes-time
node.description: An upper-bound on the time thate stale routes will be retained by a router after a session is restarted. If an End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths will be purged. This timer is referred to as the Selection_Deferral_Timer in RFC4724None

node.name: helper-only
node.description: Enable graceful-restart in helper mode only. When this leaf is set, the local system does not retain forwarding its own state during a restart, but supports procedures for the receiving speaker, as defined in RFC4724.None

node.description: Parameters related to the use of multiple paths for the same NLRINone

node.description: Maximum number of parallel paths to consider when using BGP multipath. The default is use a single path.None

node.name: route-selection-options
node.description: Parameters relating to options for route selectionNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to route selection optionsNone

node.name: always-compare-med
node.description: Compare multi-exit discriminator (MED) value from different ASes when selecting the best route. The default behavior is to only compare MEDs for paths received from the same AS.None

node.name: ignore-as-path-length
node.description: Ignore the AS path length when selecting the best path. The default is to use the AS path length and prefer paths with shorter length.None

node.name: external-compare-router-id
node.description: When comparing similar routes received from external BGP peers, use the router-id as a criterion to select the active path.None

node.name: advertise-inactive-routes
node.description: Advertise inactive routes to external peers. The default is to only advertise active routes.None

node.name: enable-aigp
node.description: Flag to enable sending / receiving accumulated IGP attribute in routing updatesNone

node.name: ignore-next-hop-igp-metric
node.description: Ignore the IGP metric to the next-hop when calculating BGP best-path. The default is to select the route for which the metric to the next-hop is lowestNone

node.name: restart-timer
node.description: Time interval in seconds after which the BGP session is re-established after being torn down due to exceeding the max-prefix limit.None

node.name: state
node.description: State information relating to the prefix-limit for the AFI-SAFINone

node.name: max-prefixes
node.description: Maximum number of prefixes that will be accepted from the neighbourNone

node.name: prevent-teardown
node.description: Do not tear down the BGP session when the maximum prefix limit is exceeded, but rather only log a warning. The default of this leaf is false, such that when it is not specified, the session is torn down.None

node.name: shutdown-threshold-pct
node.description: Threshold on number of prefixes that can be received from a neighbour before generation of warning messages or log entries. Expressed as a percentage of max-prefixesNone

node.name: restart-timer
node.description: Time interval in seconds after which the BGP session is re-established after being torn down due to exceeding the max-prefix limit.None

node.name: dynamic-neighbor-prefixes
node.description: A list of IP prefixes from which the system should: - Accept connections to the BGP daemon - Dynamically configure a BGP neighbor corresponding to the source address of the remote system, using the parameters of the specified peer-group. For such neighbors, an entry within the neighbor list should be created, indicating that the peer was dynamically configured, and referencing the peer-group from which the configuration was derived.None

node.name: dynamic-neighbor-prefix
node.description: An individual prefix from which dynamic neighbor connections are allowed.None

node.name: prefix
node.description: Reference to the IP prefix from which source connections are allowed for the dynamic neighbor group.None

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to the source prefix for the dynamic BGP neighbor connections.None

node.name: prefix
node.description: The IP prefix within which the source address of the remote BGP speaker must fall to be considered eligible to the dynamically configured.None

node.name: peer-group
node.description: The peer-group within which the dynamic neighbor will be configured. The configuration parameters used for the dynamic neighbor are those specified within the referenced peer group.None

node.name: state
node.description: Operational state parameters relating to the source prefix for the dynamic BGP neighbor connections.None

node.name: prefix
node.description: The IP prefix within which the source address of the remote BGP speaker must fall to be considered eligible to the dynamically configured.None

node.name: peer-group
node.description: The peer-group within which the dynamic neighbor will be configured. The configuration parameters used for the dynamic neighbor are those specified within the referenced peer group.None

node.name: neighbors

node.name: neighbor
node.description: List of BGP neighbors configured on the local system, uniquely identified by peer IPv[46] addressNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to the BGP neighbor or groupNone

node.name: peer-group
node.description: The peer-group with which this neighbor is associatedNone

node.name: neighbor-address
node.description: Address of the BGP peer, either in IPv4 or IPv6None

node.name: enabled
node.description: Whether the BGP peer is enabled. In cases where the enabled leaf is set to false, the local system should not initiate connections to the neighbor, and should not respond to TCP connections attempts from the neighbor. If the state of the BGP session is ESTABLISHED at the time that this leaf is set to false, the BGP session should be ceased.None

node.name: peer-as
node.description: AS number of the peer.None

node.name: local-as
node.description: The local autonomous system number that is to be used when establishing sessions with the remote peer or peer group, if this differs from the global BGP router autonomous system number.None

node.name: peer-type
node.description: Explicitly designate the peer or peer group as internal (iBGP) or external (eBGP).None

node.name: auth-password
node.description: Configures an MD5 authentication password for use with neighboring devices.None

node.name: remove-private-as
node.description: Remove private AS numbers from updates sent to peers - when this leaf is not specified, the AS_PATH attribute should be sent to the peer unchangedNone

node.name: route-flap-damping
node.description: Enable route flap damping.None

node.name: send-community

node.name: last-established
node.description:
This timestamp indicates the time that the BGP session last transitioned in or out of the Established state. The value is the timestamp in seconds relative to the Unix Epoch (Jan 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC).
The BGP session uptime can be computed by clients as the difference between this value and the current time in UTC (assuming the session is in the ESTABLISHED state, per the session-state leaf).None

node.name: established-transitions
node.description: Number of transitions to the Established state for the neighbor session. This value is analogous to the bgpPeerFsmEstablishedTransitions object from the standard BGP-4 MIBNone

node.description: Time interval in seconds between attempts to establish a session with the peer.None

node.name: hold-time
node.description: Time interval in seconds that a BGP session will be considered active in the absence of keepalive or other messages from the peer. The hold-time is typically set to 3x the keepalive-interval.None

node.name: keepalive-interval
node.description: Time interval in seconds between transmission of keepalive messages to the neighbor. Typically set to 1/3 the hold-time.None

node.name: minimum-advertisement-interval
node.description: Minimum time which must elapse between subsequent UPDATE messages relating to a common set of NLRI being transmitted to a peer. This timer is referred to as MinRouteAdvertisementIntervalTimer by RFC 4721 and serves to reduce the number of UPDATE messages transmitted when a particular set of NLRI exhibit instability.None

node.description: Enable or disable the graceful-restart capability.None

node.name: restart-time
node.description: Estimated time (in seconds) for the local BGP speaker to restart a session. This value is advertise in the graceful restart BGP capability. This is a 12-bit value, referred to as Restart Time in RFC4724. Per RFC4724, the suggested default value is &lt= the hold-time value.None

node.name: stale-routes-time
node.description: An upper-bound on the time thate stale routes will be retained by a router after a session is restarted. If an End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths will be purged. This timer is referred to as the Selection_Deferral_Timer in RFC4724None

node.name: helper-only
node.description: Enable graceful-restart in helper mode only. When this leaf is set, the local system does not retain forwarding its own state during a restart, but supports procedures for the receiving speaker, as defined in RFC4724.None

node.description: State information associated with graceful-restartNone

node.name: enabled

node.name: stale-routes-time

If an End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths will be purged. node.name: helper-only

node.name: allow-multiple-as

node.name: peer-groups
node.description: Configuration for BGP peer-groupsNone

node.name: peer-group
node.description: List of BGP peer-groups configured on the local system - uniquely identified by peer-group nameNone

node.name: peer-group-name
node.description: Reference to the name of the BGP peer-group used as a key in the peer-group listNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to the BGP neighbor or groupNone

node.name: peer-group-name
node.description: Name of the BGP peer-groupNone

node.name: peer-as
node.description: AS number of the peer.None

node.name: local-as
node.description: The local autonomous system number that is to be used when establishing sessions with the remote peer or peer group, if this differs from the global BGP router autonomous system number.None

node.name: peer-type
node.description: Explicitly designate the peer or peer group as internal (iBGP) or external (eBGP).None

node.name: auth-password
node.description: Configures an MD5 authentication password for use with neighboring devices.None

node.name: remove-private-as
node.description: Remove private AS numbers from updates sent to peers - when this leaf is not specified, the AS_PATH attribute should be sent to the peer unchangedNone

node.name: route-flap-damping
node.description: Enable route flap damping.None

node.name: send-community
node.description: Specify which types of community should be sent to the neighbor or group. The default is to not send the community attributeNone

node.name: description
node.description: An optional textual description (intended primarily for use with a peer or groupNone

node.description: State information relating to the BGP peer-groupNone

node.description: Name of the BGP peer-groupNone

node.description: AS number of the peer.None

node.name: local-as

node.name: peer-type
node.description: Explicitly designate the peer or peer group as internal (iBGP) or external (eBGP).None

node.name: auth-password
node.description: Configures an MD5 authentication password for use with neighboring devices.None

node.name: remove-private-as
node.description: Remove private AS numbers from updates sent to peers - when this leaf is not specified, the AS_PATH attribute should be sent to the peer unchangedNone

node.name: route-flap-damping
node.description: Enable route flap damping.None

node.name: send-community
node.description: Specify which types of community should be sent to the neighbor or group. The default is to not send the community attributeNone

node.name: description
node.description: An optional textual description (intended primarily for use with a peer or groupNone

node.name: total-paths
node.description: Total number of BGP paths within the contextNone

node.name: total-prefixes
node.description: Total number of BGP prefixes received within the contextNone

node.name: timers
node.description: Timers related to a BGP peer-groupNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to timers used for the BGP neighbor or peer groupNone

node.name: connect-retry
node.description: Time interval in seconds between attempts to establish a session with the peer.None

node.name: hold-time
node.description: Time interval in seconds that a BGP session will be considered active in the absence of keepalive or other messages from the peer. The hold-time is typically set to 3x the keepalive-interval.None

node.name: keepalive-interval
node.description: Time interval in seconds between transmission of keepalive messages to the neighbor. Typically set to 1/3 the hold-time.None

node.name: minimum-advertisement-interval
node.description: Minimum time which must elapse between subsequent UPDATE messages relating to a common set of NLRI being transmitted to a peer. This timer is referred to as MinRouteAdvertisementIntervalTimer by RFC 4721 and serves to reduce the number of UPDATE messages transmitted when a particular set of NLRI exhibit instability.None

node.name: state
node.description: State information relating to the timers used for the BGP groupNone

node.name: connect-retry
node.description: Time interval in seconds between attempts to establish a session with the peer.None

node.name: hold-time
node.description: Time interval in seconds that a BGP session will be considered active in the absence of keepalive or other messages from the peer. The hold-time is typically set to 3x the keepalive-interval.None

node.name: keepalive-interval
node.description: Time interval in seconds between transmission of keepalive messages to the neighbor. Typically set to 1/3 the hold-time.None

node.name: minimum-advertisement-interval
node.description: Minimum time which must elapse between subsequent UPDATE messages relating to a common set of NLRI being transmitted to a peer. This timer is referred to as MinRouteAdvertisementIntervalTimer by RFC 4721 and serves to reduce the number of UPDATE messages transmitted when a particular set of NLRI exhibit instability.None

node.name: transport
node.description: Transport session parameters for the BGP peer-groupNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to the transport session(s) used for the BGP neighbor or groupNone

node.name: tcp-mss
node.description: Sets the max segment size for BGP TCP sessions.None

node.name: mtu-discovery
node.description: Turns path mtu discovery for BGP TCP sessions on (true) or off (false)None

node.name: passive-mode
node.description: Wait for peers to issue requests to open a BGP session, rather than initiating sessions from the local router.None

node.name: local-address
node.description: Set the local IP (either IPv4 or IPv6) address to use for the session when sending BGP update messages. This may be expressed as either an IP address or reference to the name of an interface.None

node.name: state
node.description: State information relating to the transport session(s) used for the BGP neighbor or groupNone

node.name: tcp-mss
node.description: Sets the max segment size for BGP TCP sessions.None

node.name: mtu-discovery
node.description: Turns path mtu discovery for BGP TCP sessions on (true) or off (false)None

node.name: passive-mode
node.description: Wait for peers to issue requests to open a BGP session, rather than initiating sessions from the local router.None

node.name: local-address
node.description: Set the local IP (either IPv4 or IPv6) address to use for the session when sending BGP update messages. This may be expressed as either an IP address or reference to the name of an interface.None

node.name: error-handling
node.description: Error handling parameters used for the BGP peer-groupNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters enabling or modifying the behavior or enhanced error handling mechanisms for the BGP groupNone

node.name: treat-as-withdraw
node.description: Specify whether erroneous UPDATE messages for which the NLRI can be extracted are reated as though the NLRI is withdrawn - avoiding session resetNone

node.name: state
node.description: State information relating to enhanced error handling mechanisms for the BGP groupNone

node.name: treat-as-withdraw
node.description: Specify whether erroneous UPDATE messages for which the NLRI can be extracted are reated as though the NLRI is withdrawn - avoiding session resetNone

node.name: graceful-restart
node.description: Parameters relating the graceful restart mechanism for BGPNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to graceful-restartNone

node.name: enabled
node.description: Enable or disable the graceful-restart capability.None

node.name: restart-time
node.description: Estimated time (in seconds) for the local BGP speaker to restart a session. This value is advertise in the graceful restart BGP capability. This is a 12-bit value, referred to as Restart Time in RFC4724. Per RFC4724, the suggested default value is &lt= the hold-time value.None

node.name: stale-routes-time
node.description: An upper-bound on the time thate stale routes will be retained by a router after a session is restarted. If an End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths will be purged. This timer is referred to as the Selection_Deferral_Timer in RFC4724None

node.name: helper-only
node.description: Enable graceful-restart in helper mode only. When this leaf is set, the local system does not retain forwarding its own state during a restart, but supports procedures for the receiving speaker, as defined in RFC4724.None

node.name: state
node.description: State information associated with graceful-restartNone

node.name: enabled
node.description: Enable or disable the graceful-restart capability.None

node.name: restart-time
node.description: Estimated time (in seconds) for the local BGP speaker to restart a session. This value is advertise in the graceful restart BGP capability. This is a 12-bit value, referred to as Restart Time in RFC4724. Per RFC4724, the suggested default value is &lt= the hold-time value.None

node.name: stale-routes-time
node.description: An upper-bound on the time thate stale routes will be retained by a router after a session is restarted. If an End-of-RIB (EOR) marker is received prior to this timer expiring stale-routes will be flushed upon its receipt - if no EOR is received, then when this timer expires stale paths will be purged. This timer is referred to as the Selection_Deferral_Timer in RFC4724None

node.name: helper-only
node.description: Enable graceful-restart in helper mode only. When this leaf is set, the local system does not retain forwarding its own state during a restart, but supports procedures for the receiving speaker, as defined in RFC4724.None

node.name: logging-options
node.description: Logging options for events related to the BGP neighbor or groupNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters enabling or modifying logging for events relating to the BGPgroupNone

node.name: log-neighbor-state-changes
node.description: Configure logging of peer state changes. Default is to enable logging of peer state changes.None

node.name: state
node.description: State information relating to logging for the BGP neighbor or groupNone

node.name: log-neighbor-state-changes
node.description: Configure logging of peer state changes. Default is to enable logging of peer state changes.None

node.name: ebgp-multihop
node.description: eBGP multi-hop parameters for the BGPgroupNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to eBGP multihop for the BGP groupNone

node.name: enabled

node.name: multihop-ttl
node.description: Time-to-live value to use when packets are sent to the referenced group or neighbors and ebgp-multihop is enabledNone

node.name: state
node.description: State information for eBGP multihop, for the BGP neighbor or groupNone

node.name: enabled
node.description: When enabled the referenced group or neighbors are permitted to be indirectly connected - including cases where the TTL can be decremented between the BGP peersNone

node.name: multihop-ttl
node.description: Time-to-live value to use when packets are sent to the referenced group or neighbors and ebgp-multihop is enabledNone

node.name: route-reflector
node.description: Route reflector parameters for the BGPgroupNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuraton parameters relating to route reflection for the BGPgroupNone

node.name: route-reflector-cluster-id
node.description: route-reflector cluster id to use when local router is configured as a route reflector. Commonly set at the group level, but allows a different cluster id to be set for each neighbor.None

node.name: route-reflector-client
node.description: Configure the neighbor as a route reflector client.None

node.name: state
node.description: State information relating to route reflection for the BGPgroupNone

node.name: route-reflector-cluster-id
node.description: route-reflector cluster id to use when local router is configured as a route reflector. Commonly set at the group level, but allows a different cluster id to be set for each neighbor.None

node.name: route-reflector-client
node.description: Configure the neighbor as a route reflector client.None

node.name: as-path-options
node.description: AS_PATH manipulation parameters for the BGP neighbor or groupNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to AS_PATH manipulation for the BGP peer or groupNone

node.name: allow-own-as
node.description: Specify the number of occurrences of the local BGP speaker's AS that can occur within the AS_PATH before it is rejected.None

node.name: replace-peer-as
node.description: Replace occurrences of the peer's AS in the AS_PATH with the local autonomous system numberNone

node.name: state
node.description: State information relating to the AS_PATH manipulation mechanisms for the BGP peer or groupNone

node.name: allow-own-as
node.description: Specify the number of occurrences of the local BGP speaker's AS that can occur within the AS_PATH before it is rejected.None

node.name: replace-peer-as
node.description: Replace occurrences of the peer's AS in the AS_PATH with the local autonomous system numberNone

node.name: add-paths
node.description: Parameters relating to the advertisement and receipt of multiple paths for a single NLRI (add-paths)None

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to ADD_PATHSNone

node.name: receive
node.description: Enable ability to receive multiple path advertisements for an NLRI from the neighbor or groupNone

node.name: send-max
node.description: The maximum number of paths to advertise to neighbors for a single NLRINone

node.name: eligible-prefix-policy
node.description: A reference to a routing policy which can be used to restrict the prefixes for which add-paths is enabledNone

node.description: State information associated with ADD_PATHSNone

node.name: receive
node.description: Enable ability to receive multiple path advertisements for an NLRI from the neighbor or groupNone

node.name: send-max
node.description: The maximum number of paths to advertise to neighbors for a single NLRINone

node.name: eligible-prefix-policy
node.description: A reference to a routing policy which can be used to restrict the prefixes for which add-paths is enabledNone

node.name: use-multiple-paths
node.description: Parameters related to the use of multiple paths for the same NLRINone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to multipathNone

node.name: enabled
node.description: Whether the use of multiple paths for the same NLRI is enabled for the neighbor. This value is overridden by any more specific configuration value.None

node.description: State parameters relating to multipathNone

node.name: enabled

node.name: maximum-paths
node.description: Maximum number of parallel paths to consider when using BGP multipath. The default is use a single path.None

node.name: apply-policy
node.description: Anchor point for routing policies in the model. Import and export policies are with respect to the local routing table, i.e., export (send) and import (receive), depending on the context.None

node.name: config
node.description: Policy configuration data.None

node.name: import-policy
node.description: list of policy names in sequence to be applied on receiving a routing update in the current context, e.g., for the current peer group, neighbor, address family, etc.None

node.name: default-import-policy
node.description: explicitly set a default policy if no policy definition in the import policy chain is satisfied.None

node.name: export-policy
node.description: list of policy names in sequence to be applied on sending a routing update in the current context, e.g., for the current peer group, neighbor, address family, etc.None

node.name: default-export-policy
node.description: explicitly set a default policy if no policy definition in the export policy chain is satisfied.None

node.name: route-selection-options
node.description: Parameters relating to options for route selectionNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to route selection optionsNone

node.name: always-compare-med
node.description: Compare multi-exit discriminator (MED) value from different ASes when selecting the best route. The default behavior is to only compare MEDs for paths received from the same AS.None

node.name: ignore-as-path-length
node.description: Ignore the AS path length when selecting the best path. The default is to use the AS path length and prefer paths with shorter length.None

node.name: external-compare-router-id
node.description: When comparing similar routes received from external BGP peers, use the router-id as a criterion to select the active path.None

node.name: advertise-inactive-routes
node.description: Advertise inactive routes to external peers. The default is to only advertise active routes.None

node.name: enable-aigp
node.description: Flag to enable sending / receiving accumulated IGP attribute in routing updatesNone

node.name: ignore-next-hop-igp-metric
node.description: Ignore the IGP metric to the next-hop when calculating BGP best-path. The default is to select the route for which the metric to the next-hop is lowestNone

node.description: Maximum number of prefixes that will be accepted from the neighbourNone

node.name: prevent-teardown
node.description: Do not tear down the BGP session when the maximum prefix limit is exceeded, but rather only log a warning. The default of this leaf is false, such that when it is not specified, the session is torn down.None

node.name: shutdown-threshold-pct
node.description: Threshold on number of prefixes that can be received from a neighbour before generation of warning messages or log entries. Expressed as a percentage of max-prefixesNone

node.name: restart-timer
node.description: Time interval in seconds after which the BGP session is re-established after being torn down due to exceeding the max-prefix limit.None

node.name: prevent-teardown
node.description: Do not tear down the BGP session when the maximum prefix limit is exceeded, but rather only log a warning. The default of this leaf is false, such that when it is not specified, the session is torn down.None

node.name: shutdown-threshold-pct
node.description: Threshold on number of prefixes that can be received from a neighbour before generation of warning messages or log entries. Expressed as a percentage of max-prefixesNone

node.name: restart-timer
node.description: Time interval in seconds after which the BGP session is re-established after being torn down due to exceeding the max-prefix limit.None

node.description: A 32-bit number represented as a dotted quad assigned to each router running the OSPFv2 protocol. This number should be unique within the autonomous systemNone

node.name: summary-route-cost-mode
node.description: Specify how costs for the summary routes should be specified as per the behaviour in the original OSPF specification RFC1583, or alternatively whether the revised behaviour described in RFC2328 should be utilisedNone

node.name: igp-shortcuts
node.description: When this leaf is set to true, OSPFv2 will route traffic to a remote system via any LSP to the system that is marked as shortcut eligible.None

node.name: log-adjacency-changes
node.description: When this leaf is set to true, a log message will be generated when the state of an OSPFv2 neighbour changes.None

node.name: hide-transit-only-networks
node.description: When this leaf is set to true, do not advertise prefixes into OSPFv2 that correspond to transit interfaces, as per the behaviour discussed in RFC6860.None

node.description: Configuration and operational state parameters relating to setting the OSPFv2 maximum metric.None

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters relating to setting the OSPFv2 maximum metric for a set of advertised entities.None

node.name: set
node.description: When this leaf is set to true, all non-stub interfaces of the local system are advertised with the maximum metric, such that the router does not act as a transit system, (similarly to the IS-IS overload functionality).None

node.name: timeout
node.description: The delay, in seconds, after which the advertisement of entities with the maximum metric should be cleared, and the system reverts to the default, or configured, metrics.None

node.name: include
node.description: By default, the maximum metric is advertised for all non-stub interfaces of a device. When identities are specified within this leaf-list, additional entities are also advertised with the maximum metric according to the values within the list.None

node.name: trigger
node.description: By default, the maximum metric is only advertised when the max-metric/set leaf is specified as true. In the case that identities are specified within this list, they provide additional triggers (e.g., system boot) that may cause the max-metric to be set. In this case, the system should still honour the timeout specified by the max-metric/timeout leaf, and clear the max-metric advertisements after the expiration of this timer.None

node.name: default-metric
node.description: ISIS default metric value. This is a metric understood by every Intermediate system in the domain. Each circuit shall have a positive integral value assigned for this metric. The value may be associated with any objective function of the circuit, but by convention is intended to measure the capacity of the circuit for handling traffic, for example, its throughput in bits-per-second. Higher values indicate a lower capacity.None

node.name: unreserved-bandwidth
node.description: The amount of bandwidth reservable in this direction on this link. Note that for oversubscription purposes, this can be greater than the bandwidth of the link. It contains eight 32-bit IEEE floating point numbers(one for each priority). The units are bytes (not bits!) per second. The values correspond to the bandwidth that can be reserved with a setup priority of 0 through 7, arranged in increasing order with priority 0 occurring at the start of the sub-TLV, and priority 7 at the end of the sub-TLV.None

node.name: link-loss
node.description: Link packet loss as a percentage of the total traffic sent over a configurable interval. The basic unit is 0.000003%, where (2^24 - 2) is 50.331642%. This value is the highest packet-loss percentage that can be expressed (the assumption being that precision is more important on high-speed links than the ability to advertise loss rates greater than this, and that high- speed links with over 50% loss are unusable). Therefore, measured values that are larger than the field maximum SHOULD be encoded as the maximum value.None

node.name: residual-bandwidth
node.description: This container defines unidirectional residual bandwidth.None

node.name: state
node.description: State parameters of IS Extended Reachability sub-TLV 37.None

node.name: subtlv-type
node.description: The type of subTLV being described. The type of subTLV is expressed as a canonical name.None

node.name: residual-bandwidth
node.description: Residual bandwidth on a link,forwarding adjacency [RFC4206], or bundled link in IEEE floating-point format with units of bytes per second. For a link or forwarding adjacency, residual bandwidth is defined to be the Maximum Bandwidth [RFC5305] minus the bandwidth currently allocated to RSVP-TE label switched paths. For a bundled link, residual bandwidth is defined to be the sum of the component link residual bandwidths.None

node.name: available-bandwidth
node.description: This container defines unidirectional lavailable bandwidth.None

node.name: state
node.description: State parameters of IS Extended Reachability sub-TLV 38.None

node.name: subtlv-type
node.description: The type of subTLV being described. The type of subTLV is expressed as a canonical name.None

node.name: available-bandwidth
node.description: The available bandwidth on a link, forwarding adjacency, or bundled link in IEEE floating-point format with units of bytes per second. For a link or forwarding adjacency, available bandwidth is defined to be residual bandwidth minus the measured bandwidth used for the actual forwarding of non-RSVP-TE label switched path packets. For a bundled link, available bandwidth is defined to be the sum of the component link available bandwidths minus the measured bandwidth used for the actual forwarding of non-RSVP-TE label switched path packets. For a bundled link, available bandwidth is defined to be the sum of the component link available bandwidths.None

node.name: utilized-bandwidth
node.description: This container defines unidirectional utilized bandwidth.None

node.name: state
node.description: State parameters of IS Extended Reachability sub-TLV 39.None

node.name: subtlv-type
node.description: The type of subTLV being described. The type of subTLV is expressed as a canonical name.None

node.name: utilized-bandwidth
node.description: The bandwidth utilization on a link, forwarding adjacency, or bundled link in IEEE floating-point format with units of bytes per second. For a link or forwarding adjacency, bandwidth utilization represents the actual utilization of the link (i.e., as measured by the advertising node). For a bundled link, bandwidth utilization is defined to be the sum of the component link bandwidth utilizations.None

node.name: ipv4-source-router-id
node.description: IPv4 Source router ID address. In cases where the advertisement is an identifier for the advertising router (e.g., with the N-flag set in the Prefix Attribute Flags sub-TLV), it may be useful for other routers to know the source of the advertisement. When reachability advertisement is leaked from one level to another, Router ID advertised is always the Router ID of the IS-IS instance that originated the advertisement. This would be true even if the prefix had been learned from another protocol.None

node.name: unreserved-bandwidth
node.description: The amount of bandwidth reservable in this direction on this link. Note that for oversubscription purposes, this can be greater than the bandwidth of the link. It contains eight 32-bit IEEE floating point numbers(one for each priority). The units are bytes (not bits!) per second. The values correspond to the bandwidth that can be reserved with a setup priority of 0 through 7, arranged in increasing order with priority 0 occurring at the start of the sub-TLV, and priority 7 at the end of the sub-TLV.None

node.name: a-bit
node.description: The A bit is set when the measured value of this parameter exceeds its configured maximum threshold. The A bit is cleared when the measured value falls below its configured reuse threshold.None

node.name: link-loss
node.description: Link packet loss as a percentage of the total traffic sent over a configurable interval. The basic unit is 0.000003%, where (2^24 - 2) is 50.331642%. This value is the highest packet-loss percentage that can be expressed (the assumption being that precision is more important on high-speed links than the ability to advertise loss rates greater than this, and that high- speed links with over 50% loss are unusable). Therefore, measured values that are larger than the field maximum SHOULD be encoded as the maximum value.None

node.name: residual-bandwidth
node.description: This container defines unidirectional residual bandwidth.None

node.name: state

node.name: subtlv-type
node.description: The type of subTLV being described. The type of subTLV is expressed as a canonical name.None

node.name: residual-bandwidth
node.description: Residual bandwidth on a link,forwarding adjacency [RFC4206], or bundled link in IEEE floating-point format with units of bytes per second. For a link or forwarding adjacency, residual bandwidth is defined to be the Maximum Bandwidth [RFC5305] minus the bandwidth currently allocated to RSVP-TE label switched paths. For a bundled link, residual bandwidth is defined to be the sum of the component link residual bandwidths.None

node.name: available-bandwidth
node.description: This container defines unidirectional lavailable bandwidth.None

node.name: state
node.description: State parameters of IS Extended Reachability sub-TLV 38.None

node.name: subtlv-type
node.description: The type of subTLV being described. The type of subTLV is expressed as a canonical name.None

node.name: available-bandwidth
node.description: The available bandwidth on a link, forwarding adjacency, or bundled link in IEEE floating-point format with units of bytes per second. For a link or forwarding adjacency, available bandwidth is defined to be residual bandwidth minus the measured bandwidth used for the actual forwarding of non-RSVP-TE label switched path packets. For a bundled link, available bandwidth is defined to be the sum of the component link available bandwidths minus the measured bandwidth used for the actual forwarding of non-RSVP-TE label switched path packets. For a bundled link, available bandwidth is defined to be the sum of the component link available bandwidths.None

node.name: utilized-bandwidth
node.description: This container defines unidirectional utilized bandwidth.None

node.name: state

node.name: subtlv-type

node.name: utilized-bandwidth
node.description: The bandwidth utilization on a link, forwarding adjacency, or bundled link in IEEE floating-point format with units of bytes per second. For a link or forwarding adjacency, bandwidth utilization represents the actual utilization of the link (i.e., as measured by the advertising node). For a bundled link, bandwidth utilization is defined to be the sum of the component link bandwidth utilizations.None

It is encoded in 32 bits in IEEE floating point format. The units are bytes (not bits!) per second.None

node.name: unreserved-bandwidth
node.description: The amount of bandwidth reservable in this direction on this link. Note that for oversubscription purposes, this can be greater than the bandwidth of the link. It contains eight 32-bit IEEE floating point numbers(one for each priority). The units are bytes (not bits!) per second. The values correspond to the bandwidth that can be reserved with a setup priority of 0 through 7, arranged in increasing order with priority 0 occurring at the start of the sub-TLV, and priority 7 at the end of the sub-TLV.None

To preclude overflow within a traffic engineering SPF implementation, all metrics greater than or equal to MAX_PATH_METRIC SHALL be considered to have a metric of MAX_PATH_METRIC.None

node.name: subtlv-type
node.description: The type of subTLV being described. The type of subTLV is expressed as a canonical name.None

node.name: a-bit
node.description: The A bit is set when the measured value of this parameter exceeds its configured maximum threshold. The A bit is cleared when the measured value falls below its configured reuse threshold.None

node.name: link-loss
node.description: Link packet loss as a percentage of the total traffic sent over a configurable interval. The basic unit is 0.000003%, where (2^24 - 2) is 50.331642%. This value is the highest packet-loss percentage that can be expressed (the assumption being that precision is more important on high-speed links than the ability to advertise loss rates greater than this, and that high- speed links with over 50% loss are unusable). Therefore, measured values that are larger than the field maximum SHOULD be encoded as the maximum value.None

node.name: residual-bandwidth
node.description: This container defines unidirectional residual bandwidth.None

node.name: state
node.description: State parameters of IS Extended Reachability sub-TLV 37.None

node.name: subtlv-type
node.description: The type of subTLV being described. The type of subTLV is expressed as a canonical name.None

node.name: residual-bandwidth
node.description: Residual bandwidth on a link,forwarding adjacency [RFC4206], or bundled link in IEEE floating-point format with units of bytes per second. For a link or forwarding adjacency, residual bandwidth is defined to be the Maximum Bandwidth [RFC5305] minus the bandwidth currently allocated to RSVP-TE label switched paths. For a bundled link, residual bandwidth is defined to be the sum of the component link residual bandwidths.None

node.name: available-bandwidth
node.description: This container defines unidirectional lavailable bandwidth.None

node.name: state
node.description: State parameters of IS Extended Reachability sub-TLV 38.None

node.name: subtlv-type
node.description: The type of subTLV being described. The type of subTLV is expressed as a canonical name.None

node.name: available-bandwidth
node.description: The available bandwidth on a link, forwarding adjacency, or bundled link in IEEE floating-point format with units of bytes per second. For a link or forwarding adjacency, available bandwidth is defined to be residual bandwidth minus the measured bandwidth used for the actual forwarding of non-RSVP-TE label switched path packets. For a bundled link, available bandwidth is defined to be the sum of the component link available bandwidths minus the measured bandwidth used for the actual forwarding of non-RSVP-TE label switched path packets. For a bundled link, available bandwidth is defined to be the sum of the component link available bandwidths.None

node.name: utilized-bandwidth
node.description: This container defines unidirectional utilized bandwidth.None

node.name: subtlv-type

node.name: utilized-bandwidth
node.description: The bandwidth utilization on a link, forwarding adjacency, or bundled link in IEEE floating-point format with units of bytes per second. For a link or forwarding adjacency, bandwidth utilization represents the actual utilization of the link (i.e., as measured by the advertising node). For a bundled link, bandwidth utilization is defined to be the sum of the component link bandwidth utilizations.None

node.name: ipv4-source-router-id
node.description: IPv4 Source router ID address. In cases where the advertisement is an identifier for the advertising router (e.g., with the N-flag set in the Prefix Attribute Flags sub-TLV), it may be useful for other routers to know the source of the advertisement. When reachability advertisement is leaked from one level to another, Router ID advertised is always the Router ID of the IS-IS instance that originated the advertisement. This would be true even if the prefix had been learned from another protocol.None

node.name: prefix
node.description: Reference to the prefix for which the IGP-Prefix SID is to be advertisedNone

node.name: config
node.description: Configuration parameters for the IGP Prefix SID.None

node.description: The IP prefix for which the IGP prefix SID should be advertised. The value specified is a local prefix on the interface which is advertised into the IGP.None

node.description: The Segment Identifier to be used when advertising the IGP Prefix SID.None

node.description: The options associated with the IGP prefix SID for MPLS. The value of this leaf specifies the option that the SID should be advertised into the IGP with.None

node.name: state
node.description: Operational state parameters for the IGP-Prefix SID.None

node.name: prefix
node.description: The IP prefix for which the IGP prefix SID should be advertised. The value specified is a local prefix on the interface which is advertised into the IGP.None

node.name: adjacency-sids
node.description: Configuration and operational state parameters relating to the advertisement of a segment routing adjacency SID for this interface.None

node.name: adjacency-sid
node.description: An Adjacency SID to be advertised for the specified interface. The Adj-SID's identifier (the SID ID) must be unique, with flags specified indicating the parameters that should be set for the SID. Where a SID value is specified that is allocated from the SRGB, the global flag must be set by the system.None

node.name: sid-id
node.description: Reference to the segment identifier to be used by the local system.None

node.name: neighbor
node.description: Reference to the neighbor with which the Adjacency SID is associated.None

node.name: config
node.description: Configuraton parameters relating to the AdjSID.None

node.name: sid-id
node.description: The value of the Adj-SID to be advertised. Where a static SID identifier is specified, this should be advertised directly by the system. Where the DYNAMIC value is specified, this should be treated as a dynamically allocated value. When the MPLS data plane is in use the dynamic value should not fall within a reserved-label-block.None

node.name: protection-eligible
node.description: Whether the Adj-SID should be considered to be eligible for protection using IP or MPLS FRR during a network failure. When this value is set to true, the B-flag of the Adj-SID is set to 1, and the local system should provide FRR paths for the associated label forwarding entry. When it is set to false, the local system must not provide FRR for the specified LFIB entry.None

node.name: group
node.description: When set to true, the Adj-SID is indicated to be part of a group, and the G flag is set to 1 in the corresponding advertisement in the IGP.None

node.name: neighbor
node.description: The remote system on the interface with which the Adj-SID is associated.None

node.description: Operational state parameters relating to the AdjSID.None

node.name: protection-eligible
